T-Mobile Will Waive Data Fees for Music

summary-body.p: T-Mobile US will let customers listen to several popular music services without counting it toward their data use, giving up a potential revenue source to bolster its subscriber base.

link.highlight: YouTube Clashes With Labels on Rates

headline.main-hed: T-Mobile Will Waive Data Fees for Music Services
headline.deck: Customers Can Listen to Spotify, Pandora Without It Counting Toward Their Data Use

media.media-caption: T-Mobile said it is going to waive data charges when subscribers use services like Spotify, Pandora and Rhapsody.

article-body.p: T-Mobile US Inc. will let customers listen to several popular music services without counting it toward their data use, giving up a potential revenue source to bolster its subscriber base.
The country's fourth-largest wireless carrier said it is going to waive data charges when subscribers use services like Spotify, Pandora and Rhapsody.

The move is an attempt to capitalize on the appeal of music-subscription services, which have amassed tens of millions of listeners and are fast becoming indispensable features for users of electronic devices. In a sign of their growing clout, Apple Inc. agreed last month to pay $3 billionfor Beats Electronics, in large part to get its hands on the premium headphone maker's budding music service.

Carriers have built their business on demand for wireless Internet, and it's rare for one to offer free data service of any kind, much less for a popular feature. Streaming 30 minutes a day of music would consume about 900 megabytes of data a month, according to T-Mobile's own usage calculator—nearly half the allotment of a typical data plan.

link.highlight: YouTube Clashes With Labels on Rates

article-body.p: Rivals AT&T Inc. and Verizon Communications Inc. have retooled their pricing plans to collect more money from their subscribers as data use rises. T-Mobile, however, has been departing from convention in a successful effort to add subscribers.

The move follows others in which T-Mobile dropped service contracts and international data-roaming charges and paid for customers to get out of their contracts at rival carriers. Also Wednesday, T-Mobile introduced a program under which it will mail potential subscribers a loaner iPhone so they can test out its service.

Streaming-music services typically give listeners access to a huge library of music in exchange for a subscription payment or occasional ads. It is growing in popularity at the expense of digital-music purchases via services like iTunes. Amazon.com Inc. launched a new service last week, and Apple has an existing service called iTunes Radio.

AT&T has a partnership with Beats, and Sprint has one with Spotify. T-Mobile said the move to data-free use of their own music services would attract new customers and increase loyalty from its existing base. "Customers don't want us to give them a subscription-based service that we picked," Chief Executive John Legere said in an interview.

The company will offer "zero-rated" services including Pandora, Rhapsody, iHeartRadio, iTunes Radio, Slacker Radio and Spotify—services that it said cover 85% of the streaming-music traffic currently on its network. It plans to add more services to the plan based on customer feedback.

The majority of T-Mobile's customers are on plans that offer a fixed amount of data and slow subscribers' service after they reach the cap. For those on T-Mobile's $80-a-month unlimited-data plan, T-Mobile will provide free access to a music service called unRadio through a partnership with Rhapsody. It will have no advertisements and will allow unlimited skipping of songs and let users choose the ones they want to hear. All other customers, including those on older and cheaper unlimited plans, can pay $4 a month for the service.

T-Mobile also said it will launch a program called Test Drive in partnership with Apple that will allow customers to try using an iPhone free on T-Mobile's network for a week. After providing a credit card, customers will receive an iPhone 5s in the mail and can return it to any T-Mobile store. It expects at least one million people to try the program within the first year.
"The way people have to buy wireless service is archaic," Mr. Legere said. "It is going to get people to chance to try our network."
Write to Thomas Gryta at thomas.gryta@wsj.com
